comments:
Operations and Information Management 290 takes an in-depth look at various scientific perspectives on the processes through which people make decisions, with emphases on cognitive psychology of human problem solving, judgment and choice, theories of rational judgment and decision, and the mathematical theory of games. Much of the material is technically rigorous. 

Most students found this class to be “interesting” and believed that it offered “useful information.” In addition, students enjoyed this class, as it helped students to “think about decision-making in a more sophisticated way.”

Overall, students think highly of Professor Simonsohn, regarding him as “thought provoking” and “interesting.” Professor Simonsohn was “approachable outside of class time and is always happy to help a student with questions.”

The class materials were somewhat “dense” and “long,” but oftentimes not covered on exams.  Prior or current enrollment in STAT 101 or the equivalent, although not required, is strongly recommended.
